I had played some total war titles. Atilla, Shogun 2, Total War 2 and Napoleon. I am told Warhammer is great, as i do love Warhammer i shall get it too, once iget a better PC, and not this silly old  Laptop.Now to review, and arigatou gozaimas for reading into introductionary line.Shogun 2 and its DLC titles tackle three different ages of the land of the rising sun, the Japan, in its different ages of Feudality, or to be precise, Shogunate and Empire. Rise of the Samurai DLC tackles the years when Samurai warriors were mearly a thing to start, and Naginata spear was something more common than a katana sword. They want to become Senpai.Shogun 2 tackles the 16th-century feudal Japan, in the aftermath of the Ōnin War during the Ashikaga Shogunate. Many clans fight for ''Emperors'' and Shoguns (the real powers) atention. Senpai notice me or Senpai let me be Senpai.And Fall of the Samurai DLC takes on the role to represent you with units that were around messing with the last feudal days of Shogun's power, before the Emperor became again the Real Power. Or that is, how you actually want to make it. Alternative ends are after all, exactly the point of such games. You are mearly placed into realistical starting positions. Future, is up to you.Make Japan all christianised? No problem. Create democratic Japan in Fall of Samurai DLC? No problem. Political aspect of the game is easy enough but affects the game regardless if you focus on it or not. It offers far less options than Medieval Total War 2 or Atilla do however. Especially in comparisment to later, the Shogun 2 is a shy imotou to her. So when you ponder whenever should you buy this game or no, let me help you. The Ai can be really complex even on easy mode. So if you seek challenge, the hardest setting will give you one for sure. For casual players, easy gives enough of brainstorming already.  It is indeed a game worth of having it played. I spent quite a sum of hours playing it, while drawing, while eating and even while cooking. No, not that it is a no brainer, but the game's dynamics, of it beein a turn based game, makes it so. So if you like turn based game and feudal Japan and you generally want to play something different than is either shooting units only Napoleon or slobered over too much and stale knights - Shogun2 with its DLC's on sale is a definite hit for you! 10/10 would buy again when on sale. Oh wait. I actually did. And play Co-Op campaign with younger imotou.*bows*

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												So, at just under 700 hours I feel like I can finally review this game properly. As of writing this we've had Rome 2 and Attilla, and the new Warhammer is under way too, but until that gets released and we can get a feel of it, Shogun 2 remains the pinacle of Total War so far.I'll try to split this up for ease of reading:Animation - The animations in this game are simply the best we've had so far. From crossed blades to beheadings (Only with DLC I think though) to men drowing on their own blood on the floor, it all looks so real. Admittedly you can see how two people have to awkwardly shuffle into what seem to be "combat lanes" and their  can be clipping due to this, this only takes a second and afterwards the fight is very fluid. Men will cheer when they rout a unit, your general swanks along cockily as he walks towards his foe, infantry lower their spears when they're close enough to charge... Its all done very well. On the campaign man, generals will pull out chairs when they run our of movement, and agents will act of small gestures and do an action when they level up, such as a ninja dropping a smoke bomb. Rome 2 and Attilla sadly lack this attention to animation, especially in fights, where combat animations are hard to see or very short. Overall, the animation of Shogun 2 is very in depth, if not without its occasional clumsy moment.Combat - Using a smaller amount of unit types makes combat a more strategic affair, as unit abilities and stats are easier as you will have access to the same units. The game uses a easy to remember but hard to master formula of sword beats spear, spear beats horse, horse beats bow and bow beats sword. On the surface this is simplistic, but your katana samurai won't last long running uphill into a spearwall. This means that each unit type has its advantages in certain situations, for example bowmen seem to be alot better at attacking a fort than defending, but they can still fit into an overall formula. Gunmen are the awkard exception to this, as at times they seem to beat everything due to their high morale shock, while at others they simply refuse to fire fast enough or fire at all, rendering them useless. Added to the mix of unit types are unit tiers, with peasant (Ashigaru), samurai, monk and hero units being respectively better yet costing alot more. This means that a balance must be struck between rather weak but cheap peasant units and more hardy samurai, though at a later point ashigaru are basically useless due to the player having a large economy. Hero units are rather unbalanced, being able to take on whole units before dying, but they are certainly not invincible and die very easily to ranged units. While there are not as many exciting units as Rome 2 or Attilla, the balance is alot better, though expect to see lots of spear ashigaru in the majority of your battles.Graphics - I run this on max, and I have to say that it still looks pretty damn nice. On lower settings however, the game looks pretty dreadful, but this then again what did you want from low graphics? Take a look at the community screenshots to decide for yourself, but I think the game looks very nice. Rome 2 suffered from always looking bland IMO, while Shogun is full of life and colour. From a short distance the graphics get abit blurry, but I guess this allows it to run smoother, and by abit blurry I mean that specific detail can't be spotted, but maybe this is just me being picky. Each person in a unit usually looks different, though Rome 2 and Attilla have more face variations. Unit clothes are nice and detailed, with monks, samurai, ashigaru all looking very different and ofcourse all the different subgroups such as bowmen adding more diversity. Naval battles are quite bad at times though, as holes are blown in the ships you can see water just awkwardly clipping through, but again this is me being picky. Overall, very nice.Sound - I don't know much about sound so this will be short, but the music is entertaining and can make you feel engaged alot of the time. Its not something I'd sit and listen to in my free time, but it fits the setting very well. One of the songs was even used by the Japanese in the Sochi olympics, so I guess it must be good! The narrator is amazing in my opinion, especially at the start when he shouts "The reign of the old shogunate... IS OVER!". Battle sounds are well done, and the choking sounds even managed to make me feel sorry for the troops every now and again.Multiplayer - While not much of a fan of just playing battles, Shogun 2 has a clan system and tournaments, so if competative play is your thing you got it! You can conquer provinces on a special multiplayer map by beating other players, which then unlocks new units for you and advisors that give bonuses. Personally, I feel like this aspect of multiplayer ruins it, as a starting player is going to have a VERY hard time beating anyone expect other new players as they are locked to basic peasant units with no buffs while higher level players have hero units and buffs such as being able to see your deployment, Multiplayer is far from fair, so if you're new a hard climb will be infront of you unless you boost, which kinda sucks for people who want to level up legit or just play for fun. On the positive side, you can do large battles, seiges and naval battles online, and the maps are well made. One AMAZING aspect of multiplayer is the ability to make your own avatar and customise him from lots of armour sets unlocked by doing the steam achievements, winning multiplayer battles and conquering regions. You can choose his banner, colour and abilities, so if you've ever wanted a daimyo called Sam Peggle who wears fabulous pink and can personally tank an entire army, you can go for it! This character customisation is the only thing that makes me play multiplayer, as otherwise I find it too unbalanced, but the prospect of new armour is too good a reward! Rome 2 and Attilla sadly lacked this aspect, which is a great shame. Finally, the entire campaign can be done in coop, and unlike Empire and Napoleon players can battle the AI instead of forcing the other player to be the opponent or auto resolving, which made coop for me. You can spectate your friends battles and they can gift you units mid battle to use to keep it from getting boring. The only problem is that you are stuck between coop or vs, so in coop if your friend on the other side of the map gets declared on you are FORCED to help, but in VS all you need to do is hold their capital for a turn, meaning you can just rush through their entire empire ignoring everything. Rome 2 and Attilla sadly didn't fix this.Campaign - Final part now, sorry if I've bored you! The map itself I find quite interesting, if not unbalanced in a way; In the south you have islands which can be heavily fortified and used as a powerbase, and also brings in naval warfare. As you get closer to the map it gets more messy, as each province can have 4 bordering provinces to be invaded from unlike the south. East and North are full of huge provinces that take ages to cross and have little need for a navy. It is alot easier to play near Kyushu as you can't be invaded from the west as the map ends, so you can focus on pushing right, while clans like Oda or Hattori will always be surrounded. Diplomacy seem off to me, with Rome 2 making more sense. Allies will randomly break all their pacts with you, neutral clans will attack or factions on the opposite ends of the map will delcare on each other. You have a family tree mechanic which is nice and reminds me of Medieval 2, and this creates a roleplay element as characters get traits and followers. When you are powerful enough all the clans unite and declare on you, which is a fun challenge as usually in TW games at this point you can't be beat by single clans, though its damn hard! The building mechanic isn't as good as Empires, but its clearer and more refined.

												Shogun 2 was my initial introduction to the Total War series and boy have they set the bar high.  I bought this game almost 6 years ago and am approaching 500 hours of total playing time and still love every second of it.  If not for about a 3 to 4 year relative dead period because of pharmacy school I'd easily have eclipsed over 1000 hours.Its a great game that has a diverse number of options to go down whether it be army compositon, diplomacy, use agents, skill trees, etc as the list goes on.  Combat is also fun to watch and not terribly difficult to master as its not as micro intensive as some other RTS games are like Starcraft 2 which is great if you are not terribly skilled (I was Gold on SC2 and then hit a massive skill wall).All in all this game got me introduced to the Total War series and has caused me to play other titles before and after its release but I still prefer this game above all the rest.  Its even got me interested in the Civ series which I will also be trying out as well.  Its a great game and I would recommend this to anyone looking to try out an RTS or Turn based strategy game whether they be a new to the genres or are a veteran....and this is is just the basic game without DLC. content:
Posted: January 2
												Best total war game ever. I was a bit indifferent with the standard Shogun 2 campaign, but the Fall of the Samurai DLC makes this game better in every possible way. If you liked empire total war and napoleon total war, this DLC is an immensely improved version. It's set in 1868, the Boshin War, where the Shogunate falls to Imperial Japan. There are line infantry, riflemen, cannons... Adding on from Napoleon total war, you can use your ships to bombard the enemy on the campaign map and DURING THE BATTLE. It's amazing. Unless the enemy uses it on you ;).Pros:The AI is much better in this game than the previous ones. All of the ships are steam powered, so naval battles are faster. British, United States, and French troops are avaliable to use. Your allies are actually helpful, they may fight with you as you all fight for the Emperorer or Shogunate and they hunt the enemy and take regions. The Imperial army is superor because they use more guns and cannons. This also means you may be fighting two different faction armies in one battle, but maybe some allies will be nearby to help. If you have a ship in port that is attacked, the port has cannons on the shore to help you.You can use a train to transport troops over long distances (if no one is blocking the railroad)When I play Rome total war, I like to play as Rome. When I play Napoleon total war, I'll play as France, usually. This game does not have an obvious choice... The imperials are easier campaigns and the shogunate campaigns are hard. I have more of a desire to explore the other factions.Management of provinces is very easy... Unlike Attila where you have to worry about food and disease as well as public order... Realistic? Yes, but very burdensome. Cannons in this game are a major improvement from Napoleon total war.The game is all-around good. I mean, I'm just listing noteworthy pros.Cons:Autoresolving ship battles almost always results in an unnecessarily large amount of damage to your ships, no matter if you are an ironclad vs a small wooden 12 gun boat.Garrisons regenerate immediately. If you attack a settlement and kill almost all of the garrison, but run out of time or barely lose and attack next turn, the entire garrison regenerates while you do not... :P (also means your garrison regenerates too, so let your garrisons die firstYou have to play fast enough or you will not unite Japan in time. I do not understand the importance of getting done by a certain time, but I had 1 more year left and needed 7 more provinces, so I had to blitz all of my forces to every enemy province. I got the last province in the winter. The armies in this game seem to move quite slowly which may be due to the fact that this campaign spans over just a few years.If you like empire total war and napoleon total war, you'll love this game.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												The mix of turn based strategy (with economical, political and diplomatic ramifications) and real time battles is still wonderful, but the need to balance timing and aggression is more important than ever. Aggressive players will feel a little cheated, while diplomats will hate Realm Divide stage. Still, Total War was always about realism and the AI's scripted actions make logical and historical sense.It's the ideal example of evolution trumping revolution in creating great video games.It's wonderfully colourful and completely unique, and it should provide the usual hundreds of hours of gameplay for the hardcore. Those worrying about a retrograde step being taken for the series shouldn't have done so - it's a classic, no question.Creative Assembly is flirting with a new audience with its totaly new and fresh multiplayer component and a streamlined overhaul of the Total War series. But underneath the polished surface lies the Total War we know and love and Shogun 2 has not lost the depth and complexity that has been established over the last ten years.

Posted: June 17, 2016
												Shogun 2 allows you to be a Japanese general in the midst of civil war, and it is one of the most authentic, fun, and challenging games set during this period. There are many different factions to choose from, although almost every faction has the same units (with differently colored armor). My favorite part of the game was the Custom Battles option, where you can choose a map, weather, and time of day, determine your units and those of you opponents, and fight. This means that you can make crazy battles; I created a battle solely of ninjas and generals, for example, which was entertaining. The units have different tactical formations and powers that you can use, and the individual soldiers have been recreated with great detail. They also speak in Japanese, which adds to the realism of the game. This game is difficult, and is not exactly a good starting point for new Total War players. I have never played a Total War game before this, so I had absolutely no idea how to do the campaign, and my first few Custom Battles were frustrating and too difficult. Yet, you do learn how to command the troops, and the game becomes very fun. The graphics are good, and the music is excellent. In addition, there are Japanese quotes on the loading screens that can inspire you. If you like feudal Japan or the movie The Last Samurai, you will love this. Recommended.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Shogun 2 is quite, a game.Let me give you a rundown:So you're playing a strategy game taking place during the sengoku-jidai ''The age of the country at war''. Essentially this was a Japanese civil war, where landlords (daimyo) are fighting for control over feudal Japan. It's quite an unique setting, and it leads to some unique and cool things (which I'll cover a bit later).I'll start off with the core gameplay; There are two core modes in the game, an overworld with a stack movement and city management game, where you're administrating armies, agents and your castle towns. This mode is super cool, since you can ambush other armies by hiding your armies in forests, have agents (like ninjas) assasinate or sabotage armies and towns and so fourth. There's also a whole financial management game (I'd reccomend auto-management and then minimal taxes if you're doing very well financially). There's also diplomacy, and, oh I won't spoil it.The other core mode is on the battlefield, where you'll have your units fight. It's super awesome going all close to the battle and seeing individual units fight. All (I think melee weapon combat) was correographed by professional users of the katana and naginata (People who practice kenjutsu and naginatajutsu). It's really freaking cool, combine that with archers and all you can get some interesting battles. You're in control of unit stacks, where each unit also has special abilities etc. There's a lot to talk about, and it's quite hard for me to explain (even though it's really simple). If you know Total War however, you'll know what to expect combat wise.Graphically this game isn't that bad, in fact it requires a lot from your pc. Since all units are rendered etc. However, even on mid-tier settings this game looks great. It's what to expect from a strategy game in my opinion.Now; what sets Shogun 2 out, is the period. You have a combination of melee units as well as ranged as well as gunpowder units. So the battlefield combat can get really interesting, since you'll take chances etc. I won't explain how it feels, just, get this game. If you can get it cheap, do so. Full price is worthy of it all though.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Total War: Shogun 2, is the Seventh game in the Total War series, and the Sequel to the Original Shogun: Total War, which was the first game of the series. Taking place in Feudal Japan following the Middle Ages, you can play as one of several warlords, or factions, whose job it is to take over and unite Japan under one ruler. Each faction has their own strengths and weaknesses, Economic, Political, and Militarily. There are several DLC's for Shogun 2, including; Rise of the Samurai, Fall of the Samurai, The Dragon War Battle, as well as several downloadable clan packs. Unlike previous games in the series, Shogun 2 takes place only in Japan and not Europe or the overall world as a whole. The tutorial is also different, in that when I tried using it, it seemed to be a series of video clips on what to do, as opposed to an actual playable tutorial, the way previous Total War games have allowed. The game is straightforward, easy to learn, and reminds me of a rebooted and upgraded version of Shingen The Ruler, which was an old NES game. I had a lot more fun with this game then I figured I would, given it's region-specific story arc and lack of a sandbox feel the way previous Total War games were. As with all Total War games, it is part real time battle strategy and tactics when in combat, and turn-based role play when not fighting enemy units. A departure from many of the previous Total War games in some ways, but a fun and interesting game in any case.

												When Total War: Shogun 2 first came out, its real-time battles made me feel like I was playing through an epic battle scenes from one of those old samurai films. 												This title is possibly the best one in the Total War series. The campaign is mostly well and the different starting positions of the clans really give you different feelings despite all of them having most of the time the very same units.The weak part of the game is - as always in CA games - the AI, especially when it comes to diplomacy... I guess the battle AI has improved a little since the absolutely terrible one in Empire TW, but nonetheless it is nothing to write home about.The multiplayer Avatar Conquest game mode and the possibility to play co-op multiplayer campaigns is brilliant. A down side may be that the waiting time to get in a battle in Avatar Conquest is a bit too long for my liking.Another thing I dislike is that - just like in Medieval 2 TW - I think gunpowder units are underpowered because of their poor range and reload rate and always get massacred by those primitive archers -_- ...On the other hand, I really like the agent system which they improved a lot since earlier titles. Also, the naval battles seem to be fun and more easily playable then in Napoleon TW for example. I do have a few concerns with naval battles, but not big enough to mention them. They are mostly ok.To finish on something positive, the absolutely immense amount of mods - quite some of them actually likable - which you can get on twcenter.net and the Steam workshop give you the possibility to enhance your game experience sooo much that - thanks to the modders - from a fairly ok game you get something really really good and you will utterly enjoy it all the time - as I do. ;)

Posted: December 22, 2013
												Yo Ho Ho Ho Ho HoThe screen is shaking, the war march is underway. Scores of Yari Arigashu, Bow Arigashu and Loan Swordsmen descend upon my castle. My meagre defence is lined up at the wall, archers at the ready and katanas sharpened. Ready for the upcoming battle. Yo Ho Ho Ho Ho HoThey fire flaming arrows at my battlements, leaving my defences as naught but charcoal and ash, and then they begin to scale the walls. A few fall and plummet to their death, the rest scale over the side and charge into my men. The sullen grey sky now full of smoke from the ruins of the wooden pallisades.Yo Ho Ho Ho Ho HoMy mens morale is dropping but they're staying steadfast in the face of certain death. I rally them with my makeshift general in the form of Katana Samurai to get my troops to hold their ground. They do. I win.This is Shogun 2.The gameplay in Shogun 2 is the pinnacle of the series, everything is fluid and just works seamlessly. From the campaign map to the battlefield, it's glorious. The graphics are beautiful too, you just sit at your seat, in your boxers covered in sweat and you can't help but gawp at some of the landscapes. The online is fun but can get samey over a period of time. This is where Shogun's Achillies heel is, it's the samey troops that every faction has. Sure they have a little variation but they look and mostly feel the same to play as.Overall, Shogun 2 is a definite purchase for any strategy fan or anyone that plays video games in general as this is, in my opinion, the magnum opus of the series.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												This game is a perfect example of a total war game done right. The game feels very polished wether that be the sleak graphics in battle, agent videos, or the neat menus and tabs on the campaign map,  everything comes together very nicely. Unlike most previous games in the series, the campaign ai is aggressive and can easily end your campaign prematurely if you make to many enemies or neglect diplomacy which is a welcome change.  Diplomacy has been improved greatly with the campaign ai generally making sensible decisions( e.g. they will usually accept any terms when close to being destroyed, allies will often offer money to assist them in wars, or offer to assist you in wars in exchange for helping them in their own)Allies  are easily the most reliable in the series and will normally not backstab you unless you are allied with a trechorous clan, have become weak and failed to maintain good relations, or triggered realm divide(more on this later) , and have even occasionally send troops to help you in battles which is a refresing change. The co-op or versus campaigns(when no connection issues are present) are a complete blast, cordinating attacks with your friends and building your empires together is satisfying and a very enjoyable experience. While it is unrealistic that you will both have armies in every battle, it is possible to give friends in the campaign units under your control in both the campaign, and on the battlefield allowing participation in eachothers battles, regardless of faction and distance from one another.Now that we have spoken about what is good about the game, I will now discuss the main problems, the battlefield ai is hit and miss. Sometimes the ai catches you by surprise  with clever use of flanking, or whittling you down with massed archers when it has missle superiorty, on the flip side the ai is prone to getting careless with it's generals, or playing far to passively on defense allowing players to take the initiave. It's most noticablely bad in sieges, where it often deploys it's troops akwardly allowing them to be dealt with easily( e.g. leaving it's archers completely undefended) and will climb the walls every time, even if a gate to the castle is wide open, causing their troops to take uneccessary casualties and morale loss. Unfortunatly though bad ai is nothing new to the total war series and  may stay this way for quite some time, however if this concerns you you may opt to allow a random player to take control of the ai armies on the campaign map to offer a (usually)greater challenge. A lot of people are uhappy about the lack of variety in the clans, while each one has it's own unique specialty, and often gets a more powerful and cheaper, variant of a certain unit type, they do all use the same units(dlcs add some unique units to each faction, as well as one or two factions with many different units) although personally this doesn't bother me to much as playing to the factions specialty allows each clan to play differently offering a unique playthrough each campaign. Finally one of the biggest issues in shogun 2 is realm devide, this mechanic happens late in the game when you take enough provinces. This causes the shogun to fear your power and declare you a enemy of the state, the result is diplomacy is thrown out the window, and inevitably all factions will declare war on you, including your allies. This mechanic is not implemted well and can often feel unfair, although mods can change the way realm devide works allowing you to easily keep your allies and friends after realm devide allowing for a much more enjoyable experience.Some people may feel intimited by the setting of the game or the flaws that i have outlined, but i can't stress enough that this game is a easily among the top total war games in the series, and in my opinion is vastly superior to it's successor rome 2. There are ways to deal with most of the games flaws which i have outlined above allowing you to take full advantage of the many great features CA nailed when making this game. Wether you are a total war fan that has not purchased shogun 2, or someone who is interested in the franchise or strategy games in general, i can't recommend this game enough.TL:DR The game is polished and has some of the best diplomacy/battles in the series, multiplayer is fun and addictive while it does have some issues(siege ai/realm devide and a lack of variety) it's in my opinion well worth the price.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												[This review is for TW: Shogun 2 - Fall of the Samurai.]My hours played speaks for itself. 1,020+ hrs played and I still come back to this game. Rome II has been out for almost a year and I just couldn't get into it the same way.I love the 'family tree' feature in this game. Being able to look back at the end of a long campaign, with my Daimyo(clan leader) now 53 yrs old, having started the game when he was 18, it's a great feeling. To remember the past battles, close calls, the sacrifices etc.  It really helps build that immersive connection, so that you actually care about your clan and your armies.Like all games, this one isn't perfect. The multiplayer could be better. I'm a big stats type of guy with a game like this, and I really felt like the end of game stats weren't as informative as they could have been. For example, when you look back through the history, it says "Won battle on this date", but that's it. I wish it said which general and included all of the stats for that specific army, etc.If you've never played a game like this, you're in for a treat. Obviously, like every other game you spend money on, you should watch some youtube 'Let's Play' videos to see what's really in store. The top-down strategic view is nicely done, coming from the Civ series, it wasn't hard for me to get used to. Having the option to enter the battles in 3d is just fantastic. These battles can be absolutely epic and it's a joy to watch them unfold, especially when you're the underdog.Now to be honest, I got my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me during my first campaign. I didn't read any tutorials and I jumped right in without paying much attention to some important bits of info. The starter clans differ in difficulty, for starters. Select auto-management for Taxes at first, this will help in not becoming overwhelmed as you add more cities to your clan's dominion.That's all for now. Grab this game if you're a Civ fan that has always dreamt of actually entering the battle in 3D!

Posted: February 19
												My main issue with this game is the battels started to become very fast and arcade like.  I say started because this style of battle never went away in the new games.  Basically what I mean is the the battles go way to fast.  They can be over in less than ten minutes which is some what ridiculous.  I love playing battle multiplayer and thats waht I spent most of my time doing in the other games but this made the battles less fun.  They are also based on a rock paper scissors style.  Basically spears beat horses, swords beat spears, and horses beat swords.  Too streamline for people who like nice tactical battles.  However, the streamline easy to learn nature of these battles makes it a good game to start playing the series with.  The battles also look beautiful and the fighting is so fun to watch.  I just wish Creative Assembly would make a more real way to fight battles like earlier.  It wouldn't be that hard to do.  In earlier installments they even had a button to make the battle basic if you did want that but still kept the normal battles a feature.  Now you may be wondering why I gave it the thumbs up but the multiplayer system in this is so well done.  The avatar conquest is such a good way of doing multiplayer battles.  Also, your units gain more experience the mroe they fight making your abttles more meaningful.  The campgain I felt was also pretty good.  I like the idea of the clans and such.  Really captured Japan well.  It's a great beginner game for people new to total war but if you are really here for instense, strategic, battles then you'll probably only play one or two campgains like me.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												This a review of the standard vanilla game without any DLC.Shogun 2 is a turn-based total war style game that has you picking a clan and trying to conquer a sizeable portion of the campaign map,Pretty standard stuff.Shogun 2 boasts some very nice graphics and a much improved user interface from some of the previous installments in the franchise. This makes managing your empire far easier and unlike previous titles you have tabs to help locate anything you might need Examples:Agents,fleets,armies etc etc.The balancing of the clans is also very good as the nature of japan and its warfare means that all clans use the same unit types. The only advantage your clan will have will be in your passive bonuses and starting location.However this balancing comes at a price:None of the playable clans in the game feel unique, they all boast the same units and buildings and tech/research trees.Players who enjoyed the unique factions and units from previous titles such as Medieval 2 total war will feel a bit let down by what this game has to offer in that area.Another problem is religion. Most factions in the game start as the shinto-buddhist religion,This wouldn't be a problem except that the other 2 religions(Christian and ikko) spread like wildfire and can quickly overwhelm your provinces. This means that you will find yourself spending large amounts of money to build structures and agents or even going to war in a attempt to slow the spread of these religions should you wish to remain buddhist.Overall Shogun 2 is a nice return to Japan for the total war series, but feels like a basic but enjoyable experience.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Where do I begin on such a deep, interesting and addictive game. As an avid member of the Total war fan base, since the original Shogun, I can safely say that this is in contention for being one of the best itterations of Total war to date. I personally consider this on par with the original Rome and Medieval 2. The positives: Streamlined but detailed campaign map, well balanced and interesing units, period aesthetics with repsect for traditional Japanese culture and extremely polished and exhilerating multiplayer componenets highlighted by the exceptional coop campaign.The negatives: Not the best optimised game I have played and can be a resource hog especially for lower end systems, playable but offers a much better experience on a more powerful PC. My only true minor complaint is that clan diversity isn't as prominent versus previous titles but this is overshadowed by more balanced gameplay.Verdict: Definitely worth a buy especially if you love grand strategy and huge armies clashing on an unrivalled scale, best purchase you will make, especially if on sale.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Remove the sword from your stomach, turn on the Karaoke machine, pull out those unwashed schoolgirl panties and get sniffin' because Shogun 2 is finally here!  All the shame you feel from dishonering your family will be washed away when you are immersed into the experience that is Shogun 2!  Feel your innter girly side by being bombarded with countless cherry blossoms...Relive the glory days of Japan before the thing that is left out of most Japanese textbooks happened...March your armies to victory with more efficiency than the Bhutan death march...Build the most glorious railroad since the Burmese railway, but with less slaves...Pwn and r4pe your enemies  more than the city of Nanking...and destroy your enemies harbors more than Pearl Harbor!  The experiences and playstyles are endless!  In all seriousness though here is my actual review....above was just my promotion of the game..I could never get in to any of the other Total War games.  I played both Rome 2 and Empire a bit, but eventually stopped playing them after a game or two.  I find this game way more fun to play and I think it is way better to look at.Here are some reasons why I think this is the best newer Total War game..-Balance.  The other Total War games can become confusing with the huge amount of other units...It takes way too long to figure out what counters what.  In this game, it is quite simple but still complex at the same time.  Horse beats archer, archer beats soldier, soldier beats horse...this rock, paper, scissors forumula makes it easy to pick up and learn.  There are still other units that add complexity, but for the most part you can rely on trusting this simple formula-Design/Graphics.  Rome 2 might look slightly better in terms of polygon count and effects, but not by much.  This game looks better overall though!  The Japanese artwork and music throughout the game really helps to immerse you.  Everything else looks nearly identical to the new Total War games, but this runs better and has better performance.-Decent unit movement, control, and COLLISION DETECTION!  One of the main reasons I always got sick of the other Total War games was because it always felt that you wern't in control of your units or armies...A group of 40 soldiers, essentially acted like one unit.  This game still isn't like other RTS games where you have control over a single unit...a single unit is still considered an army, but this concept has been improved and is actually better than it is in Rome 2.  Sending in a group of 30 or so soldier in Total War games was always lame...the individual soldiers would kinda just walk around the enemies not doing anything and every 5 seconds you would eventuall see one of your units hit someone with a sword.  This is only really a problem with melee units, but its a really big problem because it make it feel like your units arn't fighting right.  Its still an issue in this game, but units are much more likely to engage eachother in battle and not just walk around not doing anything.-The expansion!  Usually expansions in Total War games or other RTS dont really change the gameplay that much.  The expansion in this game almost turns it into a whole other game!  Without the expansion, you are just using mainly archers, sword, horses, and other simple weapons....but by installing the expansion you upgrade the technology of the Japanese by like 500 years!  This is mainly because Japan was feudalistic before the arrival of western powers...The introduction of such different weapons and technologies would seem out of place usually, but in this historical context it makes sense!  It really changes the game a lot, and it makes both versions of the game fun to play.Way better than any other Total War game I have played...which is medieval 2, empire, and Rome 2.  A great game which you can always come back to!  Tons of cool MOD support, like one where they add tons of blood and decapitations!  Awesome!8/9 Sudoku boxes!

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												This game is a perfect example of a total war game done right. The game feels very polished wether that be the sleak graphics in battle, agent videos, or the neat menus and tabs on the campaign map,  everything comes together very nicely. Unlike most previous games in the series, the campaign ai is aggressive and can easily end your campaign prematurely if you make to many enemies or neglect diplomacy which is a welcome change.  Diplomacy has been improved greatly with the campaign ai generally making sensible decisions( e.g. they will usually accept any terms when close to being destroyed, allies will often offer money to assist them in wars, or offer to assist you in wars in exchange for helping them in their own)Allies  are easily the most reliable in the series and will normally not backstab you unless you are allied with a trechorous clan, have become weak and failed to maintain good relations, or triggered realm divide(more on this later) , and have even occasionally send troops to help you in battles which is a refresing change. The co-op or versus campaigns(when no connection issues are present) are a complete blast, cordinating attacks with your friends and building your empires together is satisfying and a very enjoyable experience. While it is unrealistic that you will both have armies in every battle, it is possible to give friends in the campaign units under your control in both the campaign, and on the battlefield allowing participation in eachothers battles, regardless of faction and distance from one another.Now that we have spoken about what is good about the game, I will now discuss the main problems, the battlefield ai is hit and miss. Sometimes the ai catches you by surprise  with clever use of flanking, or whittling you down with massed archers when it has missle superiorty, on the flip side the ai is prone to getting careless with it's generals, or playing far to passively on defense allowing players to take the initiave. It's most noticablely bad in sieges, where it often deploys it's troops akwardly allowing them to be dealt with easily( e.g. leaving it's archers completely undefended) and will climb the walls every time, even if a gate to the castle is wide open, causing their troops to take uneccessary casualties and morale loss. Unfortunatly though bad ai is nothing new to the total war series and  may stay this way for quite some time, however if this concerns you you may opt to allow a random player to take control of the ai armies on the campaign map to offer a (usually)greater challenge. A lot of people are uhappy about the lack of variety in the clans, while each one has it's own unique specialty, and often gets a more powerful and cheaper, variant of a certain unit type, they do all use the same units(dlcs add some unique units to each faction, as well as one or two factions with many different units) although personally this doesn't bother me to much as playing to the factions specialty allows each clan to play differently offering a unique playthrough each campaign. Finally one of the biggest issues in shogun 2 is realm devide, this mechanic happens late in the game when you take enough provinces. This causes the shogun to fear your power and declare you a enemy of the state, the result is diplomacy is thrown out the window, and inevitably all factions will declare war on you, including your allies. This mechanic is not implemted well and can often feel unfair, although mods can change the way realm devide works allowing you to easily keep your allies and friends after realm devide allowing for a much more enjoyable experience.Some people may feel intimited by the setting of the game or the flaws that i have outlined, but i can't stress enough that this game is a easily among the top total war games in the series, and in my opinion is vastly superior to it's successor rome 2. There are ways to deal with most of the games flaws which i have outlined above allowing you to take full advantage of the many great features CA nailed when making this game. Wether you are a total war fan that has not purchased shogun 2, or someone who is interested in the franchise or strategy games in general, i can't recommend this game enough.TL:DR The game is polished and has some of the best diplomacy/battles in the series, multiplayer is fun and addictive while it does have some issues(siege ai/realm devide and a lack of variety) it's in my opinion well worth the price.

Posted: February 19
												My main issue with this game is the battels started to become very fast and arcade like.  I say started because this style of battle never went away in the new games.  Basically what I mean is the the battles go way to fast.  They can be over in less than ten minutes which is some what ridiculous.  I love playing battle multiplayer and thats waht I spent most of my time doing in the other games but this made the battles less fun.  They are also based on a rock paper scissors style.  Basically spears beat horses, swords beat spears, and horses beat swords.  Too streamline for people who like nice tactical battles.  However, the streamline easy to learn nature of these battles makes it a good game to start playing the series with.  The battles also look beautiful and the fighting is so fun to watch.  I just wish Creative Assembly would make a more real way to fight battles like earlier.  It wouldn't be that hard to do.  In earlier installments they even had a button to make the battle basic if you did want that but still kept the normal battles a feature.  Now you may be wondering why I gave it the thumbs up but the multiplayer system in this is so well done.  The avatar conquest is such a good way of doing multiplayer battles.  Also, your units gain more experience the mroe they fight making your abttles more meaningful.  The campgain I felt was also pretty good.  I like the idea of the clans and such.  Really captured Japan well.  It's a great beginner game for people new to total war but if you are really here for instense, strategic, battles then you'll probably only play one or two campgains like me.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2012
												Awesome game that goes back to the origianl Shogun: Total War formula, you can feel the influence of Sun Tzu's Art of War all over it. Katana's clash, bombs are thrown, flintlock muskets are fired, and throats are slit by shinobi in the night. The Battle AI is finally competent enough to make use of forests for ambush and avoid charging directly into your spearmen across the bridge, and finally put up a decent challenge to your forces. In Direct X 11 mode, the game looks absolutely superb, a big step up from Napoleon, and uses the new form of anti aliasing called MLAA created by AMD, which increases performance. Multiplayer is engaging, and the coop mode is simply fun to play with a friend. Now, maybe if the game didn't SINGLE THREAD in Direct X 11 mode, and we didn't have to pay for the factions already in the game as DLC, this would have been a near-perfect game.

												UhNot too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes insteadIngredients:1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour3 tablespoons sugar1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon salt1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg2 large eggs, at room temperature1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as neededNow to make it1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												To begin with, this is perhaps one of the Semi-Recent Total Wars that is deserving of a proper and postive review.Think of a time when CA was innovative with each of their titles (Yes including Empire) and when DLC was actually worth buying for a total war title. Shogun 2 in my opinion remains as one of the best Total War titles, and I would recommend this over Rome II anytime. Not that Rome II is not fun, it just doesn't feel as innovative as Shogun 2 is. Shogun 2 set in Fedual Japan has a very straightforward Rock Paper Scissors mechanic for the massive battles. Yet, it is one of the hardest battle styles to master in my opinion, not because of the diverse nations, not because of the unit power ups, and not because of overpowered special units. The game is hard because each unit counts and can mean the difference between being conquered or conquering, I still find myself having the hardest time against a large stack of units in Shogun 2 than Rome II.Shogun 2's campaign although not as extensive as the whole of Europe or the conquest of the New World, Shogun 2 is one of those games that will make you manage each province with specific priorites and strategies. Sacrificing a province in order for it to become a gold powerhouse while another province builds your katanas and cav, makes you ponder as to the desicion in order to become the shogun and conquer Kyoto, and if your ambitious enough Japan.And even with the games age, this is still beautiful, even the loading screens are easy on the eyes and give you an even more realistic interpretation of the Medieval Era of Japan. CA worked around the forced combat animations that made each unit look as if they were each a Samurai Soldier that trained with their blades before the battle. This game is not a SHAMEFUR DISPLAY rather it still stands as a beautiful, tough and fresh turn base strategy game. CA and SEGA should both take the time to go back and listen to the gamers, people responded well with Shogun 2 not because it was the newest total war title, but because it was nolstolgic and fresh. The DLC is worth buying, the base game isn't "incomplete" and battles are fun to play and watch.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												To be frank this game is simply amazing. I will split the following review into three parts starting with G, graphics, gameplay and godly awesome animations.Graphics.This game is simply beautiful. The highly detailed distance scaling units and landscape add so much to the game visually. It looks very fitting into the time period of which it is set. Other details such as falling cherry blossom flowers on the battlefield make the game's atmosphere very appealing and genuine. Although the rediculous blood effects may turn you to believe it is bad exagguration, it honestly reminds you of good samurai movies with similar effects. These small details make the game so much more fantastic.Gameplay.Total War: SHOGUN 2 has an easy to understand "food chain" of units.Spear beats cavalry, cavalry beats bows, bows beat swords and swords beat spears.This is the core of the game, however other units are thrown in as well to make it more exciting. These include matchlock units, which are basically short range gun units effective at murdering everything on the battlefield. You might think at first these are overpowered, but just like everything else in the game it has a weakness. Other missile units because of it's low range. Another example are kisho units such as ninjas who can hide on the battlefield while moving slowly or sitting idle. These units are usually weak to cavalry and missiles, so they are best at engaging melee infantry units from the flanks using their special abilities such as grenades.Retainer cards are special, well.... cards, that you can choose a limited number of to play for a battle. These retainer cards can give bonuses to your units such as +2 melee attack to all sword infantry or hinder your opponent's army with cards such as -10 ammunition for enemy bow units.The main multiplayer mode is called avatar conquest, where you create your own general and build his skills and army using veteran units, which are experienced soldiers that you can upgrade and keep in your reserve. In avatar conquest you are given a map of Japan on which you move your general across to capture provences. Each time you win a multiplayer battle you will unlock the provence you are currently standing on, which may reward you with a new specific unit or retainer card. Finally we have god damn animations.The animations in this game are fantastic. Using motion capture technologies Creative Assembly was able to create some of the most beautiful animations I have seen in a video game. From decapitations to complete entry and exit of a weapon through a man's chest, these animations happen in 1 vs 1 duels in the middle of a battlefield surrounded by other units who are also doing the same. The clipping in this game is barely noticable unless you are really looking in a high clipping scenario such as when a unit of yours moves through another unit of yours. The detail of the animations are fantastic and inserted EVERYWHERE. Interestingly there are highly detailed animations for men climbing walls, throwing flaming kindling and even firing and reloading seige weapons. Simply well done Creative Assembly, if I wore hats I would take mine off.So, well done on reading this entire review. What are you doing? Honestly? Get out there and murder some fools!

												Well, I had my first experience with the Total War franchise in Shogun 2.I bought and played all DLC's, played both the online avatar conquest and coop campaing (only once, because it is practically dead now).All the singleplayer campaings are awesome and the playability is really good.All campaings will give you large amount of play time even playing on short campaing (I only played on long, but I can tell that even the short one is at least 30-50 hours of gameplay), but the first campaing, Shogun 2, and the Shogun 2 - Fall of the Samurai were my favorites due to the style of gameplay and technology already available, since the campaing Rise of the Samurai is supposed to be set before both, and they diverge in the gameplay because you don't actually need to capture the settlement to make it yours in the Rise of the Samurais (the allegiance system). What I was more excited about was the historical battles you get to fight, really amazing how they made that so every ramdom battle turns out to feel like you were reviving the Japanese's past fights (at least for me).My only complaining is about the multiplayer, it is true, I didn't play much of the avatar conquest, but from what I played (2-3 hours) it was a real♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the coop campaing could be really awesome, but as I said, it is dead now...Summary, if you are a fan of Samurais and Japan history.. buy the game for sure! Just don't expect multiplayer...

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Hirashai! Hirashai! Come! Take a seat and hear me fellow Samurai!Yea.... kinda over the top opening line.. But! Back to the topic!I was always intrigued about Asian warfare,especially Japan and its samurai.Total War:SHOGUN 2 was the game that came before ROME 2 to the TW series known for their turn based campaign and real time-chess like battles.Shogun 2 is set durning 3 crusial time periods of Japan's history (well,one if you don't buy the DLCs...):1) Sengoku Jidai (The age of the warring states) set at 1545 when most of Japan's notorious warlords were already alive and active.2)The Gempei war,set at 1175. This war is what caused the Shogun to be the main ruler of Japan and what made the empror who ruled until then a figurehead.3)The Boshin war,set at 1865,During this war,Japan yet again fought itself to change the regime,this time the empror wins. This war also marks Japan's massive modernazetion which will lead her to be a superpower eventually,but not all are happy with this and some tradition-loving Samurai will revolt and try to take matters into their own hands (Sheesh... sounds like Mea Shearim on an asian grand scale...)Now enough with history lesson! (if you wanna know more just go to wikipedia or somthin'... thats what I did... and somehow got hooked on anime in the prosess...) Lets talk about the game!GameplayEven for an unexpirienced player to the series (which I was when I bought it) learning the controls is easy as they give you a well directed tutorial on every aspect of the game.The AI might be a bit annoying (waiting on the highest hill,setting tax rate on extreme and not getting any rebellions,betray you when you can clearly crush their arses,etc) but it is still quite well made,still,if they grind your gears,there are many wonderful mods on the community's site: twcenter.net which change gameplay for the better (some are even setting the game on different timeframes if you ever get bored with the main campaigns).GraphicsFrom my limited japanese: kire desu! Or,the game is looking f***ing beautiful! (well if your computer can run it on med-high settings and up... I seriously upgraded my rig just so I can see those tiny asians kill each other without the game moving slow! But thats just me,and if you'll know me,you will see I'm bloody wierd!).Graphics look amazing! both on the battlefield and the campaign map. If you close up durning a battle, you will see samurai and ashigaru fighting to the death,on the campaign map you can see clouds around mount Fuji,seagulls flying above ports and your generals (who used all their movement points) sitting on a stool with your clans flag in hand and relaxing (or taking a crap,they do sit like they are...). If you zoom on a unit that's been hit by a volly of arrows (considering they are not naginata or bulletproof samurais) you will see that some men will instantly die with 2-3 arrows stuck in them while some others will roll around in pain with the arrow stuck in their body (I'm pretty sure an arrow to the knee won't kill you instatly... we have the guards from Skyrim to justify this!). There is much to say about the graphics but its better for you to see everything yourselves,after all,a picture is worth a thousand words!SoundThe game sounds wonderful! When on the campaign map,a calm tune will be herd,changing from turn to turn to have the feeling of the season's changing. A tentious music will be herd during a realtime battle,until the two armies clash and the tune will become glorified and brutal to mark the horrors and beauty of war at the same time.As for the voices,in Japanese they sound amazing,the commander of the unit will respond to every command you give them as they should (they will shout "kogeki!" when you order them to attack and "zenshin!" when ordered to advance,I ain't gonna explain to ya what his words mean! use your logic,or google translate if you are in dire situation!),that massive "hai!" a unit shouts after the commander always makes me smile.On the campaign map,everyone of your figures will call you "dono" or lord in japanese and will always jabber something after you order them to do something (as I said,my japanese is LIMITED,very!),too bad the voices in english don't sound as authentic as the japanese ones as most of the accents sound very forced (and all the VA's of the game are japanese,kinda wierd...),but,at least it can make you laugh a little.I forgot to talk about the speeches a general makes before battle,but they are getting annoying and repeatable after a short while so I'll leave that aside.MultiplayerAlthough Rome 2 came out not a long time ago,there are still many honorable samurai lords who have'nt abandoned 16th centuary Japan for Roman europe!Multiplayer has two sections: online battles and multiplayer campaigns.On multiplayer campaing I don't have much to say aside from that you can play with a friend and conquer Japan together (or fight against each other for control). I haven't tried this so I won't speak aout what I do not know.Online battles is realy where Shogun 2 differs from other Total War games:It is the only game on which there is a dynamic campaign-You start with costumizing your own general (other TW games doesn't have these feature aswell which is a shame...). During the battle,if you zoom on your general you will see that he looks like you cotumized him! same goes for enemy generals!,As time passes you willl earn more costumisable armor for your general. After a battle,the game will suggest to make the unit that earned most expirience to become a veteran-veteran units are also costumizable,but,the most important thing about them is that the veteran unit can enhance their skills (as you desire) to make them better,but more costly! After your general fights enough battles he will rank up and earn skill points which will help him enhance his skills as well.One of the most important things on mp is to join a clan ASAP! after every victory you will earn clan tokens which will unlock further abilities for your veterans,to do so,simply click on a clan name,or look for a Shogun 2 group,go to the clans panell and click "mark this group as my clan" or something like that,there are clans that will only accept proven players but most will accept you with no conditions,one clan for example is "HeirOfCarthage Fans",or,if you wanna,send me a message and we can start a clan together and rule over Japan!Beaware though! Most of the players are pretty expirienced in the game and the matchmaking system will usually throw you with whatever they find,even if it means a 10 star gold player! So you might have a rough beggining but after a while,I'm sure you will master the art of war in Shogun 2! So I'll say for ya-gammbatte!Anyways,if you consider buying this game,I don't see any reason why not! It is the most refind TW game at the moment and many still play it and generally,don't buy this only if you hate strategy games,it has both guns and swords for your pleasure (empire/napoleaon and rome combined) and is a very good game.So if you somehow made it to the end of this review (and didn't skip right to the end like we Israelies usually do) all I have to say is thank you for reading this! arigatou and sayonara!P.SIf you found anything in this review offensive (like those dots...) I had no intention to insult you! Its just my stupid humor! Thats all!

												First off I love the Total War series.  These games are exceptional to say the least.  SHOGUN 2 is probably my favorite out of the franchise thus far.  The ease of map and town navigation make the game simple to jump into if you've played any of the previous Total War games.  If you haven't, the overwhelmingly helpfull "advisors" will get you through the early stages of the game rather quickly and efficiently.  What's good:- Graphics are smooth and quite detailed even when you zoom way in on units- Map control is crisp and easy to manage- Naval battles are easy to get a handle on after a few battles- The technology trees are easy to understand and plan out- It's easy to jump right in and playWhat's not so good:- Understanding what each building does or chains to easily (it took me a few games to get it right)- Not knowing what building to make keeps you from getting the right units as early as you can in the game.- The time table to win the short campain is VERY challenging- Takeda clan never wants to trade with me....... WTH Takeda!?!?!- There always seems to be SOMETHING that makes your Dynamo dishonorable, and everyone hates that.- some diplomatic solutions just plain don't work, I've tried to give children away as hostages so many times, nobody want's my kids!  they must all be brats.....All in all I love this game.  I've played it a bunch just solo.  I can't vouch for any online play however so those experiences may vary.  I hope you pick this game up and check it out.  Enjoy!

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Ever wanted to be a general in feudal Japan, controlling literally thousands of Samurai marching onto the fields witht the ultimate goal of having it all? Well now you can! Even though it was released in 2011, it still remains one of the greatest strategy games of all time 4 years later. Compared to Empire and Napolean, this has so much more of a melee focus, similar to the original few games such as Medieval and Rome (unless you have Fall of the Samurai, which I'll mention later). You spend most of your time on the campaign map, choosing strategic positions for your armies and improving your economy through the use of farms and other institutions. This being a total war, you can order your armies to sabotage and attack these civilian settlements to damage an enemy's economy and bring disarray to the people. You can also forge alliances, initiate trade and improve relations through diplomacy as well, all designed to help you take over Japan. Sounds fun, right? Well actually... it is! There's something satisfying about seeing your provinces prosper and become rich. But of course, what is the real reason you play Total War?The battles! Instead of the turn based actions of the campaign map, a real time battle takes place. You command your army to defeat the opposing side. To do this, you must employ military tactics and flank the enemy with knowledge of their strengths and weaknesses. The battles are quicker than previous titles and, thanks to the new AI, harder as well. However, I fully recommend using the Darth Mod to get the enhanced AI and gameplay features. Unfortunately, I can't say that naval battles are the same. They fell far less enjoyable and I often feel that victory comes down to who has a bigger navy rather than the appliance of tactics.Summary:Pros-- Excellent land battles that encourage the appliance of military tactics.- Terrain and weather which can help or hinder you and your opponents.- Units are mostly balanced.- Excellent campaign map.- RPG system that allows upgrades to units, generals and agents.Cons- UPDATE: Cavalry are not as meaningless as I said before. They are meant to be morale damagers, not units racking 500 kills. And Naval battles are actually quite fun. More depth than I originally thought.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												The total war series has always been my favorite, and Shogun 2 is my favorite of that series.  It has great gameplay mechanics on both the tactical and strategic levels due to a simple but elegant unit system.  Each unit excels in a certain situation, and there are enough unit types so that even after hundreds of hours, you can still innovate with units you have never really used before.  Each army build has strengths and weaknesses, and each clan favors slightly different build, giving lots of replay value.  Simple but elegant is really the theme of the game, and is carried over to the building trees, tech trees, agents, and political aspects of the game.  Each aspect of the game is simple enough to pick up and use easily, but the game is deep enough to allow a great deal of engaging and varied gameplay.  The campaign map, tactical maps, in game encyclopedia, and user interface show the attention to detail that was given during development.  In addition, I strongly recommend any and all of the DLC, but especially the Sengoku Jidai unit pack, which gives unique units to each clan.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												To be frank this game is simply amazing. I will split the following review into three parts starting with G, graphics, gameplay and godly awesome animations.Graphics.This game is simply beautiful. The highly detailed distance scaling units and landscape add so much to the game visually. It looks very fitting into the time period of which it is set. Other details such as falling cherry blossom flowers on the battlefield make the game's atmosphere very appealing and genuine. Although the rediculous blood effects may turn you to believe it is bad exagguration, it honestly reminds you of good samurai movies with similar effects. These small details make the game so much more fantastic.Gameplay.Total War: SHOGUN 2 has an easy to understand "food chain" of units.Spear beats cavalry, cavalry beats bows, bows beat swords and swords beat spears.This is the core of the game, however other units are thrown in as well to make it more exciting. These include matchlock units, which are basically short range gun units effective at murdering everything on the battlefield. You might think at first these are overpowered, but just like everything else in the game it has a weakness. Other missile units because of it's low range. Another example are kisho units such as ninjas who can hide on the battlefield while moving slowly or sitting idle. These units are usually weak to cavalry and missiles, so they are best at engaging melee infantry units from the flanks using their special abilities such as grenades.Retainer cards are special, well.... cards, that you can choose a limited number of to play for a battle. These retainer cards can give bonuses to your units such as +2 melee attack to all sword infantry or hinder your opponent's army with cards such as -10 ammunition for enemy bow units.The main multiplayer mode is called avatar conquest, where you create your own general and build his skills and army using veteran units, which are experienced soldiers that you can upgrade and keep in your reserve. In avatar conquest you are given a map of Japan on which you move your general across to capture provences. Each time you win a multiplayer battle you will unlock the provence you are currently standing on, which may reward you with a new specific unit or retainer card. Finally we have god damn animations.The animations in this game are fantastic. Using motion capture technologies Creative Assembly was able to create some of the most beautiful animations I have seen in a video game. From decapitations to complete entry and exit of a weapon through a man's chest, these animations happen in 1 vs 1 duels in the middle of a battlefield surrounded by other units who are also doing the same. The clipping in this game is barely noticable unless you are really looking in a high clipping scenario such as when a unit of yours moves through another unit of yours. The detail of the animations are fantastic and inserted EVERYWHERE. Interestingly there are highly detailed animations for men climbing walls, throwing flaming kindling and even firing and reloading seige weapons. Simply well done Creative Assembly, if I wore hats I would take mine off.So, well done on reading this entire review. What are you doing? Honestly? Get out there and murder some fools!

Posted: March 7, 2016
												To begin with, this is perhaps one of the Semi-Recent Total Wars that is deserving of a proper and postive review.Think of a time when CA was innovative with each of their titles (Yes including Empire) and when DLC was actually worth buying for a total war title. Shogun 2 in my opinion remains as one of the best Total War titles, and I would recommend this over Rome II anytime. Not that Rome II is not fun, it just doesn't feel as innovative as Shogun 2 is. Shogun 2 set in Fedual Japan has a very straightforward Rock Paper Scissors mechanic for the massive battles. Yet, it is one of the hardest battle styles to master in my opinion, not because of the diverse nations, not because of the unit power ups, and not because of overpowered special units. The game is hard because each unit counts and can mean the difference between being conquered or conquering, I still find myself having the hardest time against a large stack of units in Shogun 2 than Rome II.Shogun 2's campaign although not as extensive as the whole of Europe or the conquest of the New World, Shogun 2 is one of those games that will make you manage each province with specific priorites and strategies. Sacrificing a province in order for it to become a gold powerhouse while another province builds your katanas and cav, makes you ponder as to the desicion in order to become the shogun and conquer Kyoto, and if your ambitious enough Japan.And even with the games age, this is still beautiful, even the loading screens are easy on the eyes and give you an even more realistic interpretation of the Medieval Era of Japan. CA worked around the forced combat animations that made each unit look as if they were each a Samurai Soldier that trained with their blades before the battle. This game is not a SHAMEFUR DISPLAY rather it still stands as a beautiful, tough and fresh turn base strategy game. CA and SEGA should both take the time to go back and listen to the gamers, people responded well with Shogun 2 not because it was the newest total war title, but because it was nolstolgic and fresh. The DLC is worth buying, the base game isn't "incomplete" and battles are fun to play and watch.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												To be frank this game is simply amazing. I will split the following review into three parts starting with G, graphics, gameplay and godly awesome animations.Graphics.This game is simply beautiful. The highly detailed distance scaling units and landscape add so much to the game visually. It looks very fitting into the time period of which it is set. Other details such as falling cherry blossom flowers on the battlefield make the game's atmosphere very appealing and genuine. Although the rediculous blood effects may turn you to believe it is bad exagguration, it honestly reminds you of good samurai movies with similar effects. These small details make the game so much more fantastic.Gameplay.Total War: SHOGUN 2 has an easy to understand "food chain" of units.Spear beats cavalry, cavalry beats bows, bows beat swords and swords beat spears.This is the core of the game, however other units are thrown in as well to make it more exciting. These include matchlock units, which are basically short range gun units effective at murdering everything on the battlefield. You might think at first these are overpowered, but just like everything else in the game it has a weakness. Other missile units because of it's low range. Another example are kisho units such as ninjas who can hide on the battlefield while moving slowly or sitting idle. These units are usually weak to cavalry and missiles, so they are best at engaging melee infantry units from the flanks using their special abilities such as grenades.Retainer cards are special, well.... cards, that you can choose a limited number of to play for a battle. These retainer cards can give bonuses to your units such as +2 melee attack to all sword infantry or hinder your opponent's army with cards such as -10 ammunition for enemy bow units.The main multiplayer mode is called avatar conquest, where you create your own general and build his skills and army using veteran units, which are experienced soldiers that you can upgrade and keep in your reserve. In avatar conquest you are given a map of Japan on which you move your general across to capture provences. Each time you win a multiplayer battle you will unlock the provence you are currently standing on, which may reward you with a new specific unit or retainer card. Finally we have god damn animations.The animations in this game are fantastic. Using motion capture technologies Creative Assembly was able to create some of the most beautiful animations I have seen in a video game. From decapitations to complete entry and exit of a weapon through a man's chest, these animations happen in 1 vs 1 duels in the middle of a battlefield surrounded by other units who are also doing the same. The clipping in this game is barely noticable unless you are really looking in a high clipping scenario such as when a unit of yours moves through another unit of yours. The detail of the animations are fantastic and inserted EVERYWHERE. Interestingly there are highly detailed animations for men climbing walls, throwing flaming kindling and even firing and reloading seige weapons. Simply well done Creative Assembly, if I wore hats I would take mine off.So, well done on reading this entire review. What are you doing? Honestly? Get out there and murder some fools!

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												TW: Shogun 2 is by far one of my favorite games. The reasons being the balanced units, co-op, multiplayer, the excellent expansion that is Fall of the Samurai, unique and interesting bonuses for the majority of the clans, well placed tactical structures  on the maps, a very well designed skill tree that scales into late-game, and the manual battles are something else.However as much as I could praise any positive attribute i've previously stated in detail, i've no intention of doing so. You'd be better off not having what the game has to truly offer being spoiled. Which leads me to the negative attributes of TW: Shogun 2 because I will go into a bit of detail, and you should definitely know what you're getting into because realistically what is a minor complaint for me could be a major problem to you. Specifically within the standard campaign diplomacy is for the most part a joke. The player has options to increase their diplomatic standings with another clan, but you will face situations where neighboring clans refuse nearly all attempts at diplomacy and ultimately on the higher difficulties this means going to war early with 4 or more clans. The only ways to avoid this are to pay other clans off and/or hope you can set up a prearranged marriage, and realistically both are not an option in the early game phase. Well that or you have to choose a clan that is positioned in a corner or the Chosokabe which are on a small island. Now if you reach a certain point where you've gained too much territory there will be a realm divide and you instantly lose about 250 diplomacy with all clans meaning you're instantly at war with every remaining clan in Japan unless you've been paying them off until that event happened, and even still it's meaningless to pay that clan off because no matter what you do they'll eventually go to war with you anyway due to the fact you lose a large amount of diplomacy every turn after a realm divide. Essentially within the standard campaign at a difficulty of 'hard' or higher, the diplomacy mechanic within the game is what will literally make your life a living hell  and it gets worse as you bump up the difficulty. That isn't to say you can't win, but unless you're either willing to play co-op or sacrifice much of what you've conquered for a better tactical position you can and will be completely crushed losing all time invested in playing. Regardless though the game can still provide a challenge at normal difficulty for some time, and the hard difficulty isn't going to give you nightmares if you're well versed with the game. Anything beyond the hard difficulty obviously isn't going to be forgiving at all. Now that we're done with that, how about that Rise of the Samurai expansion? It's fairly horrible due to the same diplomacy issues, less unit types, slower gameplay due to each province needing to be converted to a specific allegiance, less building types, less potential money made per turn, etc. Buyers beware of the RoTS expansion.To end this review I want to reiterate that the Fall of the Samurai expansion is truly excellent. Most of the diplomacy issues are fixed in this expansion, there are even more unit types, a longer overall campaign in regards to available turns, siege units  matter now, a similar skill tree but with a nice twist and better economic opportunities that make it feel very different from the standard skill tree, more provinces, design changes to the overall map of Japan, etc. Personally I prefer the feudal units in the standard campaign to the more modern units in the FoTS expansion but there's still so much to enjoy here.What else can I say? Great game, but it has its faults.
