content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Easily the best Total War game since Rome and Medieval II (and it may be better than both of those), Shogun 2 takes the franchise back to where it began: Japan's Sengoku Era. You play as one of the great Daiymo lords struggling to unite the country. This is not the easiest of tasks, and it is one that inevitably involves a great deal of violence since ultimately there can only be one Shogun. Unlike previous TW games, once you reach a certain level of strength in the campaign, all of the other factions unite to fight against you, leading to an intense mid-late game. Since past TW games tended to get far too easy once you conquered enough, this is actually rather refreshing to see since it staves off boredom. Overall, the gameplay is similar to all other TW games, except here it is more polished, more focused, and altogether better than previous installments.It also has a rather unique and well-designed multiplayer system which, while unfair at times if the matchmaker puts you up against vastly more experienced foes, at least manages to give a player reasons to keep playing it. I'm not sure if anyone still plays the multiplayer, but i'd hope so. Besides, i've been given to understand that Creative Assembly made a mess of Rome 2's multiplayer (among other things), so Shogun 2's is probably a superior experience.There are flaws in this game though. The AI here is much better than in past TW games, but it still has its dummy moments. People who have crazy-good PC's may be irritated to find out that this game at its maximum settings might be too much for their computers to handle. The larger your empire gets the more micromanagement you have to do, which, although no different from previous TW games, still can be annoying for those who just want to fight the battles. Lastly there are bugs and crashes that, while not too frequent, are still frustrating when they happen.If you have an interest in this franchise but have yet to try it out, Feudal Japan in general, or really just well-made games, then this is worth checking out.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												I love the Total War franchise, but its always a gamble for me when I try out new ones. Some, like Rome: Total War, are great, with a continous development and a possibility to actually conquer most of the "world". Others, like Empire: Total war, are too difficult and slow, making expansion take forever and always leaving you exposed no matter what you do.Total War Shogun 2 has the perfect combination of continous development and difficulty. At the easy setting, you can more or less steamboat through the entire campaign, and at the hardest setting you have to plan your every single move. Personally I mostly play at the normal difficulty, where you get some opposition and have to be a bit tactical, but still see some development and progression in every other turn.As with any Total War game, there's a high replay value, as each faction offers you a new challenge, with only the end-game becoming seemingly similar. Once you've played through this game a couple of times, I recommend getting the expansions: Fall of the Samurai & Rise of the Samurai, as these will further change the gaming experience and tactics that you have to use, without changing the difficulty (as did the expansions to Rome: Total War, which made that game unplayable).Great for casual gaming, as I usually watch some tv-series or standup, with the game volume turned off.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2011
												Shogun 2 is an epic game, where the goal is to conquer Japan. Its a shame military conquest is the only way to win, compared to a game like Civ where you can also win by technology, culture or diplomacy. But the military part of Shogun is superior to anything I've played. As I write this, I've played through one campaign, and I feel like I've only scratched the surface of its tactical depth. But at the same time, as a new player to the Total War series, I never felt overwhelmed or confused. You move armies around on the campaign map, as well as managing economy, food, religion and technology. Then you fight enemy armies on the battlefield, where success depends on tactics, unit strengths and weaknesses, experience, formations, terrain, weather, morale and special abilities. The scope for replayability is immense. There are ten clans to play as, my short campaign took 13 hours, there are also long campaigns, historic battles, and multiplayer. Ignoring this would be a SHAMEFUL DISPLAY !!

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												This is probably the best of the Total War games and a must-buy if you don't already own it.It is the most tasteful and attractive visually of any of the Total War games.The scale of the regions in the campaign map make more sense than what you encounter in Rome 2 and Attila.  Rome 2 and Attila have an unfortunate and totally unrealistic game convention in which only the largest city in a region is fortified.  You're often left making bizarre defenses of towns that in reality had extensive and effective fortifications.Not only do you get none of that in Shogun 2, but what fortifications you do encounter are much more convincing than their Total War European counterparts.The game is set in three different periods.  The medieval version of Japanese history is interesting, but is something of a curiosity for when you get tired of the main game.  The big surprise is the Meiji restoration game (Fall of the Samurai): it's very different from the regular Shogun game, and a lot of fun to play.   I resisted getting it for a long time, but once I'd played around with the historical scenario a bit, I was hooked.

Posted: January 9, 2015
												The game Total War: Shogun 2 is awesome. I currently have 40 hours logged, and those 40 hours have just flown by. Total War: Shogun 2 is a strategy game where you are a lord and have to conquer Japan, along the way of becoming Shogun or Emperor you will make allies, enemies, and trade routes. The combat system is great as it has been in all Total War games. Strategies and analyzing and reacting to situations are key to winning. The new castle sieges add a new element to this franchise. Storming the walls is more tricky then one might think it would be with archers picking off melee units, it turns into a ranged battle until one side gets weakened enough for your melee troops to take to the walls. Another element Total War introduces is a co-op campaign. You have the option of trying to unite Japan with your Pal or going against him and fighting to the death till one of you end up on top. Now with the cons, I wish to co-op campaign would have supported more than two players. Another con is that the expansions aren’t as balanced as the original game. Other than those two cons I would recommend this game.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												I acquired this game because I wanted a Samurai: Total War game. It fulfills that requirement and more. The campaigns can be tough, especially since you seem to be beset by enemies, and you have a limited amount of time to fulfill your ambition of ruling Japan. This is especially true if you are at the far end of Honshu and need to march all the way to Kyoto to secure the Shogunate.And that's just the base campaign. There is a Rise DLC which puts you in the same situation about 400 years before the base one. And then there is Fall, which adds a LOT of gunpowder weaponry and modern tactics, and deals with a short period that lead to the modernization of Japan (and indirectly to the Japanese Empire of WWII).There is also a multiplayer game that can be fun, though challenging in a different way. As hard as the AI can be, other players are often craftier and less prone to being trampled underfoot by cavalry. And since those with Fall can use their weaponry it can sometimes lead to quality versus quantity matchups.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												The game Total War: Shogun 2 is awesome. I currently have 40 hours logged, and those 40 hours have just flown by. Total War: Shogun 2 is a strategy game where you are a lord and have to conquer Japan, along the way of becoming Shogun or Emperor you will make allies, enemies, and trade routes. The combat system is great as it has been in all Total War games. Strategies and analyzing and reacting to situations are key to winning. The new castle sieges add a new element to this franchise. Storming the walls is more tricky then one might think it would be with archers picking off melee units, it turns into a ranged battle until one side gets weakened enough for your melee troops to take to the walls. Another element Total War introduces is a co-op campaign. You have the option of trying to unite Japan with your Pal or going against him and fighting to the death till one of you end up on top. Now with the cons, I wish to co-op campaign would have supported more than two players. Another con is that the expansions aren’t as balanced as the original game. Other than those two cons I would recommend this game.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Easily the best Total War game since Rome and Medieval II (and it may be better than both of those), Shogun 2 takes the franchise back to where it began: Japan's Sengoku Era. You play as one of the great Daiymo lords struggling to unite the country. This is not the easiest of tasks, and it is one that inevitably involves a great deal of violence since ultimately there can only be one Shogun. Unlike previous TW games, once you reach a certain level of strength in the campaign, all of the other factions unite to fight against you, leading to an intense mid-late game. Since past TW games tended to get far too easy once you conquered enough, this is actually rather refreshing to see since it staves off boredom. Overall, the gameplay is similar to all other TW games, except here it is more polished, more focused, and altogether better than previous installments.It also has a rather unique and well-designed multiplayer system which, while unfair at times if the matchmaker puts you up against vastly more experienced foes, at least manages to give a player reasons to keep playing it. I'm not sure if anyone still plays the multiplayer, but i'd hope so. Besides, i've been given to understand that Creative Assembly made a mess of Rome 2's multiplayer (among other things), so Shogun 2's is probably a superior experience.There are flaws in this game though. The AI here is much better than in past TW games, but it still has its dummy moments. People who have crazy-good PC's may be irritated to find out that this game at its maximum settings might be too much for their computers to handle. The larger your empire gets the more micromanagement you have to do, which, although no different from previous TW games, still can be annoying for those who just want to fight the battles. Lastly there are bugs and crashes that, while not too frequent, are still frustrating when they happen.If you have an interest in this franchise but have yet to try it out, Feudal Japan in general, or really just well-made games, then this is worth checking out.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Easily the best Total War game since Rome and Medieval II (and it may be better than both of those), Shogun 2 takes the franchise back to where it began: Japan's Sengoku Era. You play as one of the great Daiymo lords struggling to unite the country. This is not the easiest of tasks, and it is one that inevitably involves a great deal of violence since ultimately there can only be one Shogun. Unlike previous TW games, once you reach a certain level of strength in the campaign, all of the other factions unite to fight against you, leading to an intense mid-late game. Since past TW games tended to get far too easy once you conquered enough, this is actually rather refreshing to see since it staves off boredom. Overall, the gameplay is similar to all other TW games, except here it is more polished, more focused, and altogether better than previous installments.It also has a rather unique and well-designed multiplayer system which, while unfair at times if the matchmaker puts you up against vastly more experienced foes, at least manages to give a player reasons to keep playing it. I'm not sure if anyone still plays the multiplayer, but i'd hope so. Besides, i've been given to understand that Creative Assembly made a mess of Rome 2's multiplayer (among other things), so Shogun 2's is probably a superior experience.There are flaws in this game though. The AI here is much better than in past TW games, but it still has its dummy moments. People who have crazy-good PC's may be irritated to find out that this game at its maximum settings might be too much for their computers to handle. The larger your empire gets the more micromanagement you have to do, which, although no different from previous TW games, still can be annoying for those who just want to fight the battles. Lastly there are bugs and crashes that, while not too frequent, are still frustrating when they happen.If you have an interest in this franchise but have yet to try it out, Feudal Japan in general, or really just well-made games, then this is worth checking out.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												This may be my favorite Total War game ever.  It captured the feeling the the original Rome: Total War created for me, but much greater running at modern standards.  The art design is absolutely stunning, creating a very realistic setting and staying to true to beautiful Japanese culture.  The vibrant colors and tranquil nature appeal to me more than the pastel-like palet of Total War: Rome II.  The textures are slightly inferior to Rome, but it is hardly noticeable which is very satisfying considering its age.The original Grand Campaign is excellent.  Boasting several prominent clans at the height of feudal Japan, each clan has something unique to offer depending on the player's style.  Generals are linked through a family tree and you must work through diplomacy to solidify your clans status.  This was the first time the game utilized a 'realm divide' system to keep the player in check from steamrolling the AI once they got their strength up.  The payer is labeled an enemy of the state once their power get's too high and nearly all other factions will make an effort to attack you.  This is a welcome challenge to previous Total War games; in prior games once you got to a certain pount you were nearly unstoppable and could conquer the world one opponent at a time.  This impacts your campaign IMMENSELY as you need to constantly plan for the oncoming civil war whilst you expand, ever thoughtful of the consequences of over expanding or failing to mainatin adequate garrisons in your back lands.The AI for Total War games has never been a standout, but it gets the job done.  Experienced players like myself should have little trouble on Legendary but must still make conscious efforts to win.  Siege battles actually play out and you'll seldom have to wait for the battle timer to run out to win a battle.  The range of difficulties offer a different challenge to players of different skill and I find Legendary difficulty extremely satisfying to play.The battles themselves play out like live-action chess matches to a degree.  Each unit has strengths and weakness to other units and excels at their role while suffering when placed outside their niche.  Eg. spear-armed units excel at defensive formations and against cavalry while being vulnerable to sword-armed units.  Missile units can extract a toll on all units, particularly ones with light armor while units of heavy armor can absorb fire with minimal losses and all missile units are extremely vulnerable to melee combat and cavalry.  Seeing as the game takes place in only Japan, the unit roster offers little diversity between factions, with certain factions yielding slightly better variations of their specialty unit.  However, this makes the game all the more strategic as each faction can field the same armies as you, with it's strengths and weaknesses.  Recent DLC has also added many unique units that add some flavor to the game and I would defnietely recommend a few of them.Lastly, the multiplayer experience is by far my favorite in any Total War, much more so than the lacking Total War: Rome II MP.  Players create and equip their own personal general with weapons, armor, and retainers that act as their avatar.  You can also join global clans to coordinate battles and create your own clan banners.  Your avatar will appear on the battlefield leading your armies.  You move your avatar on the campaign map and each battle you win will offer new bonuses depending on the province you conquered.  Units that excel in battle will be promoted and you can then customize them to stand out on the battlefield and upgrade them as they get better.  The whole system comes together nicely and several battle options and match-making options allow players to play the battles they want with other players of appropriate skill.Overall, the grand package of Total War: Shogun II was astonishing.  CA went back to its roots and pulled a nearly perfect game together.  I can say this with confidence as I have over 1,000 hours total logged into this game and only 1/2 of that in Rome II.  If you've never played Total War, this is the game to start with.  I would highly recommend it to strategy fans, historical buffs, and novices alike for the experience this game is able to create.10/10

Posted: October 10, 2013
												A polished experience with attention to details and immersive gameplay. Shogun 2 is a serious upgrade to the Total War franchise and for sure the best iteration so far.At first the Sengoku Jidai historical period might seem confusing, with lots of names and places true to the Japanese medieval setting, but after some time the essence of TW games surfaces as strong as ever. The campaigns might get long but never boring.The art and design is impeccably well presented, and the music is top-notch, even if somewhat repetitive when playing long sessions. The graphics are good and adaptable to a wide range of PCs. The interface is clear and beautiful, and I never encountered a glitch or bug in 70+ hours of gameplay.The new mechanic of Realm Divide brings freshness and challenge to the stalled and/or boring mid-to-endgame, and is a very welcome feature that will divide the weak and inconsistent from the true strategists. The AI is really not that smart, and makes very illogical decisions---many times downright stupid---when playing the lower difficulties. The best experience comes playing on Hard and above, and of course the light RPG-like multiplayer avatar system.Shogun 2 can entertain you for hours. With high replayability and infinite options, no campaign is ever the same. All DLC is worth having.If you liked previous Total War games, this is a must own. Highly recommended.

												I love the Total War franchise, but its always a gamble for me when I try out new ones. Some, like Rome: Total War, are great, with a continous development and a possibility to actually conquer most of the "world". Others, like Empire: Total war, are too difficult and slow, making expansion take forever and always leaving you exposed no matter what you do.Total War Shogun 2 has the perfect combination of continous development and difficulty. content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Total War: SHOGUN 2 is nothing short of a (slightly flawed) masterpiece.It is a remake of Creative Assembly's Shogun: Total War with vastly enhanced gameplay mechanics. The Total War series has been know to consist of turn-based real-time tactics games with a focus on historical authenticity. Total War: SHOGUN 2 does just that.Campaign:The campaign does not follow a certain group or faction throughout history. The game lets the player decide on which faction to chose from and allows the player to change history as he or she feels. The game does not restrict the player to any historical event so it lacks historical authenticity in place of player choice.Gameplay:The gameplay is very smooth. Animations were well made and the graphics are extremely detailed. The game uses the flawed Warscape engine as its backbone to run the animations and gameplay mechanics. The engine limited the game (units could only fight in 1 v 1 combat). Luckily, the engine does not ruin the game unlike the games before and after Total War: SHOGUN 2. Multiplayer:The multiplayer utilizes a new multiplayer campaign map where the player has to win matches to unlock a map regions which in turn unlock new unit types and bonuses to aid in online matches. Unfortunately, the multiplayer scene has depleted to the more recent Total War games.Summary:Overall, the game is very robust and can still stand the test of time.DLC:The best DLC to get is the Rise of the Samurai Campaign. It unlocks a whole host of units and buildings that require the player to plan new tactics and strategies. All other DLCs contribute minorly to the game (e.g. hero units and new starting locations).

content:
Posted: September 3, 2011
												Shogun 2 is the greatest Total War game ever, and one of my favorite games of all time. If you don't own this and are into strategy games at all, I very highly recommend it.Shogun 2 offers a more refined and polished experience than any other Total War title. The base game is set in the Sengoku Jidai, beginning in 1545. Shogun 2 examines warfare in fuedal Japan more closely and accurately than any other game, with an array of samurai, ashigaru, monk, and European units.The DLC campaign, Rise of the Samurai, takes you back to the Gempei War, beginning in 1175. Units unique to this time period are used, including early samurai, levies, and sou. Most noticeable in this earlier form of Japanese warfare is the complete absence of gunpowder, the relative newness of the samurai class, and the loose unit formations. Rise of the Samurai is an experience unique from that of the base game's campaign, and is definitely worth purchasing.Fall of the Samurai, the standalone expansion to Shogun 2, is set during the Boshin War, beginning in 1865. The explosive rise of the modern era in Japan that began with the end of its isolation ignited a civil war between those dedicated to the cause of restoring the emperor to power, and those who remained loyal to the Tokugawa shogun. Warfare during this time period features extensive use of rifles and artillery, as the time of the samurai class approaches its end. Traditional units are still available, and useful, to recruit however.All three campaigns for Shogun 2 offer unique experiences that warrant multiple playthroughs. Shogun 2 also features excellent multiplayer progression, through experience unlocks and a unique veteran unit system, and features multiplayer matchmaking, as well as two player online campaigns. All of the DLC for Shogun 2 is worth purchasing, though some may wish to pass on the unit packs. The faction packs offer unique factions unlike anything else found in the base game, and are definitely worth purchasing. I, myself, would recommend all the DLC, as the units included in the packs are fun, unique units.Shogun 2 is a masterpiece RTS/TBS hybrid, and showcases epic, historically authentic samurai warfare unlike anything else.

												Addictive, engaging, and absolutely stunning in its art direction and gameplay, Shogun II: Total War is a masterpiece in the Total War franchise that combined most pleasing aspects from previous Total War games without becoming tiresome. 												Total War: Shogun 2: ReviewIn this game, you are a power hungry warlord climbing the ladders of leadership set in Feudal Japan. content:
Posted: June 29, 2011
												Shogun 2 is an epic game, where the goal is to conquer Japan. Its a shame military conquest is the only way to win, compared to a game like Civ where you can also win by technology, culture or diplomacy. But the military part of Shogun is superior to anything I've played. As I write this, I've played through one campaign, and I feel like I've only scratched the surface of its tactical depth. But at the same time, as a new player to the Total War series, I never felt overwhelmed or confused. You move armies around on the campaign map, as well as managing economy, food, religion and technology. Then you fight enemy armies on the battlefield, where success depends on tactics, unit strengths and weaknesses, experience, formations, terrain, weather, morale and special abilities. The scope for replayability is immense. There are ten clans to play as, my short campaign took 13 hours, there are also long campaigns, historic battles, and multiplayer. Ignoring this would be a SHAMEFUL DISPLAY !!

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Twice the ShogunCreative Assembly revisits the Sengoku period of Japan with Shogun 2: Total War. The game feels like an extension of their previous title Napoleon: Total War with the faster paced movement, morale effects, and some AI elements, but in the end delivers a fresh new Total War game you’d be more than happy to sink your teeth into.GameplayThe heavy focus on melee troops will kind of throw you off if you have been playing a lot of Empire/Napoleon, but the same rock/paper/scissors tactics will apply here. Typically there are three types of units you’ll see in a battle. Spear/Sword units who do all of your fighting, Ranged/Archer units for supporting your battle lines, and Cavalry units that can flank and take care of the supporting units behind the front lines. These types of units are then broken down into quality (Ashigaru or Samurai), and unique versions (Matchlock, Cannons, Bow Cav, etc). Combined with a standard set of battle maps to play on and plenty of castle sieging, things will start to look and feel the same after your initial play through of a short campaign.Sieging in this game is also handled differently. Do you know how Japanese people got past a Castle’s walls in the 16th century? Ladders? No. Grappling Hooks? Nope. Siege Towers? Uh-uh. They scaled the walls with their bare hands and climbed that♥♥♥♥♥♥like a man. All units are able to scale the walls. Troop disposition and location of attack is more important here since your men will suffer casualties getting to the wall (archers), climbing up the wall (falling off), and then fighting garrisoned forces inside. Burning down a door presents a more direct way of getting inside, but also a nasty choke point for the defenders to trap you in. Also, Castles can be upgraded to provide more tiers of walls to go through, elevation changes, little moats with a handful of places to ford across and Towers to help fend off attackers.Castle Sieging brings out a fault of this game early on, since there’s only one battle map per Castle tier. So if you fight a Tier 1 castle in one province and then go next door and siege another Tier 1 castle, they will look exactly the same. Standard battle maps are also limited in selection and you will start to recognize them early on. This is kind of disappointing since this has been an issue in the past games. You think they would introduce some sort of map generator/randomizer by now.Elevation plays more of a factor now since units charging uphill not only move slower, but suffer a penalty to attack doing so. This means battles are mostly focused around or on top of a defensible hill. Shock units (units with a high charge value) are also more effective in this game, able to decimate and route units within seconds in some situations. Battles play out faster so you’ll have to adjust your lines quickly and use your General frequently to provide morale boosts. Babysitting troops will make it hard to watch the awesome new highly detailed units and brutal fighting animations.The naval stuff isn’t as good as the old Empire or Napoleon ship battles, mostly because you’ll be fighting with arrows. Essentially, there are boarding ships with a greater amount of Samurai to board with, Ranged/support boats with faster ships, and unique gunpowder ships that toss grenades and mines. There are a few canon ships in the game and the dreaded “Black Ship” with 60 cannons but it’s mostly just alot of boarding and surrendering, nothing very explosive like a proper 18th century ship battle. Not exactly a fault of the game, just the time period.      GraphicsSpeaking of which, the graphics engine is reminiscent of Napoleon: Total War. There are prettier fire and smoke effects, but the big push was made in the detailed units and fighting animations. You can see units intricate armor and weapons they’re equipped with. The fighting animations are exciting to watch (alot of dudes get stabbed through the face). The lighting and shadows are done very well and weather effects do not look cheesy. There are alot of fog effects and clouds sailing through the skies which adds a nice atmosphere to the setting.The 3D Campaign map with a moveable camera is a welcome addition, but not necessarily needed or useful. Using it just makes me lose orientation of the map, so I hardly bothered rotating the map at all. It was only useful selecting some troops hidden behind some one else’s flag.MultiplayerA heavy focus was put into multiplayer for this game as there are plenty of features to choose from, a customizeable and persistent character you can level up with, and best of all, a Co-op Campaign mode! The latter is fully featured and plays out like you would expect, essentially a single player coop with another person. The battles can be fought between you and your partner, you can gift him units on the battlefield to control or if he is the reinforcing army, he will take control of his own forces. There is an adversial campaign mode as well. I experienced a steady flow of glitches and bugs during an online coop relating to the campaign map and not being able to finish my turn, and also not being able to join a coop game at all. I hope that these will eventually get ironed out.AIThe AI have been improved some since the last Total War game, but you'll still witness the random cavalry unit charge all by itself straight into your lines, awkward unit placement, and little focus on out manuevering your lines or flanking period. I was happy to see that the AI can form proper battle lines for the most part and it is also able to determine the best defensible hill to perch upon. You'll be glad to hear that the General doesn't charge into certain death as much as he used to, but he'll dismount and siege a castle's walls if he is the last unit left for some reason. I guess honor before death right? With that said, the AI has made some noticeable improvements but not all is perfect. Although having the option to have Drop-in battles is nice, it's just an excuse for poor AI to be present in the game. It would be nice to have an AI that would try and flank you every once in awhile.As far as the Campaign Map goes, the AI does a decent job there as well. Allies are involved more when attacking an enemy, the AI does a good job on moving armies together for support, and also not sending in smaller sized armies to attack you. On the higher difficulty settings there is some noticeable cheating going on with the AI being able to afford lots of Armies even with only a few provinces.Shogun 2 is a solid release for the franchise, no game breaking bugs, a nice change up in the style of gameplay, and a different setting besides war torn America and Eurasia to fight in. I'm glad they chose to revisit Shogun and implement what they have learned as well as new technology into it. If you're looking for a new Grand Strategy game, give this one a try. And if you're already a Total War fan, why are you reading this instead of conquering Japan?

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												For the Shogunate !Total War : Shogun 2 or Shogun 2 : Total War ReviewThis is my first (or third total war game , if you count empire and the original shogun demos) . Suffice to say I'm rather new to this type or Turn-Based Strategy with Real Time Tactics game. And yet this game is able to capture my attention for the first time I played the tutorial. Perhaps its because I'm new to this genre, the addiction of seeing my armies tactically win a skirmish because of good position attacks is strangely satisfying. Taking a severe loss can be heart brokening especially if you had the advantage. Outnumbering the enemy that has 2000 troops defending a castle with 6000 troops has it... tingling feeling (and the evil thought of the enemy army being obliterated) and some goosebumps as well. Those are the feeling that I have when playing Total War : Shogun 2. Now onto the review itself.For the new user experience (new to this genre) , it can be... quite the game depending on what happens. For me it was literally a giant puzzle, the tutorial explained well, but was painfully slow to listen to , its skippable, but too much inportant info lies there. 												Shogun 2, in my opinion, is one of the greatest grand strategy games that the world has to offer.You need a good, fast computer if you want to run this game at full settings, but when you can, the gameplay is breathtaking!         PROS- AMAZING GRAPHICS- You can always switch gameplay up by taking on the roles of different clans or objectives( so it never gets old)- custom battles ( you can fight massive battles with over thousands of soldiers in each army( may lag a bit if too many soldiers)- game uses invisible hand type controls to guide troops( best type of controls for these types of games)- tons of units to mix and match in armies( for custom and in campaign.- historical accuracy (although units dont have scabbards for swords)- this game is BEYOND realistic.    CONSThe game tends to lag if you top 3000 troops for battles.It takes a while to learn all the controls.THIS IS A BIG ONE! There are a lot of DLCs (downloadable content) You can download additional clans, units, and campaigns.However, you tend to ask yourself, didn't I pay 30 dollars for this already?As I said, Shogun 2 is one of the best grand strategy games you can get. If you are looking for realistic, action packed, combat/strategy games, and you don't mind going old school, SHOGUN 2 IS FOR YOU!GOOD JOB SEGA AND CREATIVE ASSEMBLY! KEEP UP THE GOOD WORK!!!!

												In Japanese, they are usually referred to as bushi (武士?, [bu.ɕi]) or buke (武家?). According to translator William Scott Wilson: "In Chinese, the character 侍 was originally a verb meaning "to wait upon" or "accompany persons" in the upper ranks of society, and this is also true of the original term in Japanese, saburau. In both countries the terms were nominalized to mean "those who serve in close attendance to the nobility", the pronunciation in Japanese changing to saburai. According to Wilson, an early reference to the word "samurai" appears in the Kokin Wakashū (905–914), the first imperial anthology of poems, completed in the first part of the 10th century.[1]By the end of the 12th century, samurai became almost entirely synonymous with bushi, and the word was closely associated with the middle and upper echelons of the warrior class. The samurai were usually associated with a clan and their lord, were trained as officers in military tactics and grand strategy, and they followed a set of rules that later came to be known as the bushidō. While the samurai numbered less than 10% of then Japan's population,[2] their teachings can still be found today in both everyday life and in modern Japanese martial arts.Following the Battle of Hakusukinoe against Tang China and Silla in 663 AD, which led to a retreat from Korean affairs, Japan underwent widespread reform. One of the most important was that of the Taika Reform, issued by Prince Naka-no-Ōe (Emperor Tenji) in 646 AD. This edict allowed the Japanese aristocracy to adopt the Tang dynasty political structure, bureaucracy, culture, religion, and philosophy.[3] As part of the Taihō Code of 702 AD, and the later Yōrō Code,[4] the population was required to report regularly for census, a precursor for national conscription. With an understanding of how the population was distributed, Emperor Mommu introduced a law whereby 1 in 3–4 adult males was drafted into the national military. These soldiers were required to supply their own weapons, and in-return were exempted from duties and taxes.[3] This was one of the first attempts by the Imperial government to form an organized army modeled after the Chinese system. It was called "Gundan-Sei" (ja:軍団制) by later historians and is believed to have been short-lived.[citation needed]The Taihō Code classified most of the Imperial bureaucrats into 12 ranks, each divided into two sub-ranks, 1st rank being the highest adviser to the Emperor. Those of 6th rank and below were referred to as "samurai" and dealt with day-to-day affairs. Although these "samurai" were civilian public servants, the name is believed[by whom?] to have derived from this term. Military men, however, would not be referred to as "samurai" for many more centuries.[citation needed]In the early Heian period, during the late 8th and early 9th centuries, Emperor Kammu sought to consolidate and expand his rule in northern Honshū, and sent military campaigns against the Emishi, who resisted the governance of the Kyoto-based imperial court. Emperor Kammu introduced the title of sei'i-taishōgun (征夷大将軍), or Shogun, and began to rely on the powerful regional clans to conquer the Emishi. Skilled in mounted combat and archery (kyūdō), these clan warriors became the Emperor's preferred tool for putting down rebellions; the most well known of which was Sakanoue no Tamuramaro. Though this is the first known use of the "Shogun" title, it was a temporary title, and was not imbued with political power until the 13th century. At this time (the 7th to 9th century), the Imperial Court officials considered them to be merely a military section under the control of the Imperial Court.Samurai on horseback, wearing ō-yoroi armour, carrying bow (yumi) and arrows in a yebira quiverUltimately, Emperor Kammu disbanded his army. From this time, the Emperor's power gradually declined. While the Emperor was still the ruler, powerful clans around Kyoto assumed positions as ministers, and their relatives bought positions as magistrates. To amass wealth and repay their debts, magistrates often imposed heavy taxes, resulting in many farmers becoming landless.[citation needed] Through protective agreements and political marriages, they accumulated, or gathered, political power, eventually surpassing the traditional aristocracy.[citation needed]Some clans were originally formed by farmers who had taken up arms to protect themselves from the Imperial magistrates sent to govern their lands and collect taxes. These clans formed alliances to protect themselves against more powerful clans, and by the mid-Heian period they had adopted characteristic Japanese armor and weapons, and laid the foundations of Bushidō, their ethical code.After the Genpei war of the late 12th century, a clan leader Minamoto no Yoritomo obtained the right to appoint shugo and jito, and was allowed to organize soldiers and police, and to collect a certain amount of tax. Initially, their responsibility was restricted to arresting rebels and collecting needed army provisions, and they were forbidden from interfering with Kokushi officials, but their responsibility gradually expanded and thus, the samurai-class appeared as the political ruling power in Japan. Minamoto no Yoritomo started the Kamakura shogunate in 1192.Kamakura Bakufu and the rise of samuraiSamurai ō-yoroi armour, Kamakura period. Tokyo National Museum.Originally the Emperor and non-warrior nobility employed these warrior nobles. In time, they amassed enough manpower, resources and political backing in the form of alliances with one another, to establish the first samurai-dominated government. As the power of these regional clans grew, their chief was typically a distant relative of the Emperor and a lesser member of either the Fujiwara, Minamoto, or Taira clans. Though originally sent to provincial areas for a fixed four-year term as a magistrate, the toryo declined to return to the capital when their terms ended, and their sons inherited their positions and continued to lead the clans in putting down rebellions throughout Japan during the middle- and later-Heian period. Because of their rising military and economic power, the warriors ultimately became a new force in the politics of the Imperial court. Their involvement in the Hōgen-era Hōgen Rebellion in the late Heian period consolidated their power, which later pitted the rivalry of Minamoto and Taira clans against each other in the Heiji Rebellion of 1160.The winner, Taira no Kiyomori, became an imperial advisor, and was the first warrior to attain such a position. He eventually seized control of the central government, establishing the first samurai-dominated government and relegating the Emperor to figurehead status. However, the Taira clan was still very conservative when compared to its eventual successor, the Minamoto, and instead of expanding or strengthening its military might, the clan had its women marry Emperors and exercise control through the Emperor.The Taira and the Minamoto clashed again in 1180, beginning the Gempei War, which ended in 1185. Samurai fought at the naval battle of Dan-no-ura, at the Shimonoseki Strait which separates Honshu and Kyushu in 1185. The victorious Minamoto no Yoritomo established the superiority of the samurai over the aristocracy. In 1190 he visited Kyoto and in 1192 became Sei'i-taishōgun, establishing the Kamakura Shogunate, or Kamakura Bakufu. Instead of ruling from Kyoto, he set up the Shogunate in Kamakura, near his base of power. "Bakufu" means "tent government", taken from the encampments the soldiers would live in, in accordance with the Bakufu's status as a military government.[5]Ashikaga ShogunateThe Samurai Suenaga facing Mongols, during the Mongol invasions of Japan. 												I loved this game and have recently gotten back into it but all the Total War games eventually get ridiculous. Let me explain.So me and my friend are dominating Japan, we have 40 provinces, and there are only a total of four factions left (me, him, hojo, takeda). It's me and him vs those two. We're pushing and doing very well and the fights are beginning to get bigger and tougher as we enter their deeper lands... Okay, no problem. Then it gets to the point where my armies, even though they have just as good units and more than the enemy, will all of a sudden ALL run away at the exact same time. This happened first to my friend who was destroying the enemy army and then all of a sudden everyone panicked. We thought he was flanked, we thought something actually happened. Nope. This happened to me 3 times after that and him again. We are very frustrated that the PC cheats like that. To make matters worse, the more recent TW games have gotten even worse than this one. Rome 2 took the PC cheating to the extreme where no matter how good your strategy was or how well your soldiers were doing, some battles... you were losing no matter what. Then Attila came out and that game is almost impossible to play because you're constantly losing ground. You have better units and you outnumber the enemy but who cares, it's CA so "♥♥♥♥ you!" All your units throw down their weapons, pull down their pants, turn around, and bend over for the enemy to come and have their way with them.I'm done with the Total War series.
